text: Saying all fraternity members are bad is like saying all police are bad, or all members of a certain race or religion are bad, or all football players are bad, or any other number of groups people of all political views paint as a whole because they are in a particular group.  Just like anything else, there are good fraternities and bad ones, good members and bad ones.  Mine happens to be a good one.  We do community service for Toys for Tots every year, raise money for under privileged families every year with fund raisers, do member development retreats, and hold a high standard for members GPAs, and have among the highest of any group on campus.  I graduated 17 years ago and still donate time and money, and so do many others who are active in our alumni association.  We also have a strict anti hazing policy today...in the 90's when I pledged we did not and I went through the old way, but fortunately we have come a long way in 20 years.  Beyond this many of us have made lifetime bonds.  My little brother in the fraternity is still my closest friend after all these years, and I am now in business with another brother and his dad.  Alot of value can come out of a fraternity if the individuals want to be men rather than immature slobs.  Mine happens to be a good one, full of ambitious and mature young men, they even saved up to buy a chapter house and don't even allow any parties or underage drinking there.  Same can't be said about others, many have come and gone since I was in school.  But to paint them all as bad because of some bad ones out there is ignorant.

context_meta.title: British man accused of 'indecently touching' businessman in Dubai sentenced to a month in prison for drinking alcohol
context_meta.summary: A British man facing an accusation that he ‘indecently touched’ a businessman in a bar in Dubai has been sentenced to a month in prison for drinking alcohol. Jamie Harron, 27, is facing a possible three-year sentence after allegedly touching the man’s hip in a bar. Mr Harron, who has been stripped of his passport, was convicted and sentenced for drinking alcohol in advance of his trial on ‘public indecency’.

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Fla. doctor apologizes after video shows him yelling, cursing at patient
context_meta.summary: A Florida doctor, who was seen yelling and cursing at a patient in a now-viral video, said he did so because the woman was "abusive to the office staff," according to a statement he released on Wednesday. Peter Gallogly, a physician at the Gainesville After Hours Clinic in northern Florida, said the video was the last minute of an "hour-long episode" with Jessica Stipe, who he says became irate and refused to leave the office. Stipe, who shared a video of the incident on her Facebook page Monday, said she was "in severe pain and throwing up in the trash can" when she complained about the long wait time and asked for her co-pay back, according to her Facebook post.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Brazilian who led U.S. to $17 million under mattress to plead guilty
context_meta.summary: A Brazilian whose arrest led U.S. authorities to discover $17 million hidden under a mattress is expected to plead guilty on Wednesday after being charged with trying to launder funds tied to one of the largest pyramid schemes ever. Cleber Rene Rizerio Rocha, who prosecutors said tried to help get millions of dollars out of the United States that a co-founder of TelexFree Inc left behind when he fled the country, is scheduled to enter his plea in federal court in Boston. Rocha, who faced conspiracy and money laundering charges, has been held without bail since his arrest in January.

context_meta.title: He threw a man onto subway tracks — then tried to keep others from rescuing him, police say
context_meta.summary: Suddenly, he felt a sharp blow to his back — and then he was tumbling onto the train tracks. Ben Benedict, 46, had been waiting for a train on a subway platform in downtown Chicago, headed home from a Cubs game, when a man ran at him and shoved him with both hands onto the tracks, according to the Chicago Tribune. Benedict sprained his wrist as he fell, and he almost landed directly on the track's potentially deadly, electrified third rail, the Tribune reports. Police say the incident happened just before midnight on Aug. 1 at the CTA's Washington Blue Line station. But on Tuesday evening, detectives scoured the streets around the home where Alina Sheykhet was found murdered. They searched in trash cans, bushes, fire escapes and storm drains. “There's just cops absolutely everywhere,” said Peyton Miller, who lives on the street and knew both the victim and now her alleged murderer.
